coredata.dc:title: Influence of solvent properties on fluorescence probes. 7-amino- and 7-n-dimethylamino-4-methylcoumarin
coredata.dc:creator: Coosemans, L.
De Schryver, F.C.
Van Dormael, A.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The shift of the maximum wavenumber of 7-amino- and 7-N-dimethylamino-4-methylcoumarin as a function of solvent properties is investigated and compared to that of other probes. The observed changes are interpreted on the basis of solvent polarity and, specially, of solvent cohesion, unifying previous interpretations by Kosower and Reeves.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 65, number I CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 August 1979 INFLUENCE OF SOLVENT PROPERTIES ON FLUORESCENCE PROBES. 7-AMINO- AND 7-N-DIMETHYLAMINO-4-METHYLCOUMARIN L COOSEMANS, F.C- DE SCHRYVER and A. VAN DORMAEL Department of dentistry. University ofLeuven. 8-3030 Hei eriee. Belgium Receiied 22 January 1979; in final form 16 March 1979 The shift of the nia\imum ivavenuinber of 7-amino- and 7-N-dimelliyIamino-4-nictli> Icoumarin as a function of sohent propetties is ini estimated and mmpared to that of other probes. Tlie observed clianae;> arc interpreted on the basis of soh ent polarity and, specially, of sohent cohesion, unifying previous interpretations by Kosoucr and Reeies. 1. Introduction Intensity and spectral changes of ionic dyes and flu- orescence probes [1—7] have been used to study bind- ing sites of these molecules to macromolecules. The change in spectrum on binding is compared with the spectroscopic properties of the probes in a series of or- ganic solvents or solvent mixtures to simulate the in- fluence of the environment. To make the comparison meaningful a coherent model of the influence of the solvent on these spectral probes is needed- Several sol- vent parameters [8—16] were deduced on the basis of empirical relations between spectral changes and the solvent, or on the basis of macroscopic properties of the solvent. Her'orandson and Neufeld [11] suggested the use of the Hildebrand parameter, 5, and discussed its relation to other parameters, and it was used by Reeves [17] to explain the spectroscopic properties of 6-toluidino- 2-naphthalene sulfonate (TNS). In other studies on the same probe [18—20] the spectral changes are re- lated to solvent polarity as measured by the empirical parameter £'-? (30). In this work the spectral changes of two non-ionie fluorescence probes are related both to the solvent polarity (/FT (30)) and to tlie solvent cohesion (5) and compared with TNS. 2. Materials and method 7-N-dimethylamino-4-iTiethylcouniarin (la) and 7- amino-4-methylcoumarin (Ib) were synthetised ac- cording to a method described [21 ]. Compounds la and Ib were purified by column chromatography (silicagel, eluens CHCL}) crystallized from water and recrystallized from cyclohexane. The structure v.as checked by conventional spectroscopic methods. All solvents used were of spectroscopic or pro analysis quality, and were carefully cliecked for the absence of fluorescent impurities. Emission spectra of la and Ib in pure solvents were taken on a Fica 55 Specirotluori- metre Absolu. Emission spectra in solvent mixtures were determined on a Spex Fluorolog. The spectra were corrected for excitation and for the response of the apparatus. 3. Results The position of the emission maxima of la and Ib is in agreement with some earlier reported results [22]- In table 1 a list of the solvents- in which the fluores- cence maxima were determined and their relevant sol- vent parameters is given togetlier with the emission maxiina of la and Ib in wavenumbers. No correlation was obtained between the position of the emission maximum and the dielectric constant (DK.) or the more complex Bayliss solvent parameter [23]. A dou- ble linear dependence was found on plotting the wave- 95 Volume 65, number I CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS I August 1979 Table 1 n-hc-one <H) benzene <B) tlt0\anc (D) lelrahydrofiiran (Till-') chloroform (0 dichloromethane (MC) dimcthyllbrin.initdc (DM1-") f-bulanol tTBA> tlimcihytsul{b\nte (DMSO> isopropanol (IP) ettmnol (E) methanol (\() clhylencslycol (EC) glicerot (Gy) water (\V) DK") /b) £-T(30C) 5d) ^maxdo) "max^ 1.88 0-00 30.9 7.3 26810 25572 2.28 0.003 34.5 9-2 25510 24450 2-21 0.020 36 10.0 25253 24331 7.58 0.210 37.4 9-1 24814 23981 4.81 0.148 39-1 93. 24631 23SIO 9.08 0.219 41.1 9.7 25126 23585 36-71 0-275 43.S 12.1 24038 23068 12.47 0.251 43.9 10.0 23374 22857 46-68 0.267 45 12.0 23585 22676 19-92 0-273 58.6 11-5 23474 22678 ''4.58 0-''88 51-9 12.7 23256 T»T?-> 32-70 0-308 55-5 14-5 23148 22026 37.7 0.276 56.3 14-6 22936 21645 42^ 0.264 57 16-5 22936 21552 80.2 0-320 63.1 23.4 22523 21231 ^ReC-1251- M<DK.-I»/(2DK+1)-(«2 - l)/(2H2 * 1). c) Ref- (181. in kcal/niol. d) Ref. [18], in cal/cm3- number of the emission maximum of la and Ib as a function of £"-(-(30) in fifteen solvents (fig-1). The flu- orescence behavior of both probes varies in a similar fashion, and the relation between the waveninnbers of their emission maxima can be expressed as follows: I-'ie- 1- Fluorescence maxima <if the aminocciiniarins (a: Ib; br la) in diftercnt solvents as a function of£"-J-(30). Solvent designations arc as in table 1. i^(la) = -1473 + 1.02 ^axOb)- (1) The correlation coefficient for this relation equals 05S7. Plotting of the data obtained by Reeves [17] * on TNS in a series of solvents as a function of the .£'-?• (30) parameter shows a double linear dependency as com- pounds la and Ib (fig. 2). In analogy with the work ofKosower [20] on 6-N- arylamino-2-naphthalenesulfonates the fluorescence properties of la and Ib were investigated in dioxane— water mixtures, claimed to be an excellent polarity scale in terms of the Ef (30) parameter. The wavenum- ber of the emission maxima of la and Ib against the A'-r-(30) value of the different mixtures is plotted in fig. 3 and shows, as in the pure solvents, the same dou- ble linear dependence for both probes. The relation be- tween i^^(Ia) and i^naxO b) can be expressed as ?n^(Ia) = -2786 + 1.07 ^(lb). (2) with a correlation coefficient of 0580- A similar double linear dependency is found for TNS in dioxane—water mixtures [20]- The importance of solvent cohesion in the influence of a solvent on the spectral properties of a probe was stressed by Reeves 'Reeves claims "the emission nia.\imuni is correlated poorly by the Reichardt and Dimroth E values in 17 solvents (r = 0.85)1171". 96 Volume 65, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 August 1979 24000 v (cm') Fig. 2- 1-Tuorescence maxima ofTNS (data from ref. [71 in different solvents as a function of£'-p(30). Sohent designa- tions are as in table 1 and Ac: aceton; DMAe: dimeth\I- acetaniide: NBA: n-butanol; BA: benzyl alcohol. Fig. 4. Plot of the emission maxima of the aminocoumarins (a: lb;b: la) in hvdro\^ I soli ents against the Hildebrand 6 parameter. [17]. This aspect was investigated by plotting the waveimmber of the emission maximum of la and Ib against the 5 parameter of seven hydroxyl solvents (fig. 4). A linear dependence is observed for both probes with a correlation coefficient of 0.97 for la and 0.92 for Ib. The latter value is raised to 0.989 if the result obtained in water is not taken into account 2EOOO ^c,n1) 2SOOG (vide infra). The influence of solvent structure on the spectral properties of the probes was studied in t- butanol—water mixtures. The addition off-butanol to water enhances the organisation of the aqueous phase and this effect is maximal at six mole percent added alcohol. In this solvent mixture a double linear depen- dence is observed (Hg. 5) witli an inflexion at six mole percent of added r-butanol. The influence of viscosity on the fluorescence properties of la was investigated in ethanol. A strong liypsochromic shift is observed close to the temperature dt which ethanol forms a glass. Fig. 3. Fluorescence maxima of the aminocoumarins (a: Ib; b: la) in dioxane— water mixtures as a function of£-r-(30). Values of£"T'(30) for these mixtures are obtained from ref -1231- Fig. 5- Plot of the emission mavima of the annnocourrLirins (a: lb;b. la) in r-butJnol— water nuvima against the composi- tion in mole percentage of the mixture. 97 Volume 65. number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 August 1979 4. Discussion A double linear dependence between the emission maximum and the £'-[-(30) parameter is observed for both probes la and Ib and for TNS in dioxane—water and in a series of solvents- These results are in agree- ment with those obtained by Turner and Brand [I] for TNS who plotted the emission maximum as a function of the Kosower Z parameter, which is linearly related to the A'-p (30) parameter (161.Good correlation ob- tained for both probes la and Ib in a series of solvents indicates that the observed phenomena are mostly due to non-specific solvent— probe interaction. The solvent effect, as measured by the /FT (30) pa- rameter, is in contrast to TNS smaller at the highest solvent polarity for la and Ib. If the interpretation of the TNS d.ita proposed by Kosower [20] is extrapo- lated for the probes la and Ib. this should indicate that tlie least polar form of the aminocouniarins is ob- tained in the solvent with the highest polarity. How- ever. the second linear part of the plot of the emission maximum as a function of£"-p(30) is in fact due to emission in hydroxyt, or better, structured solvents. The influence of the solvent on the emission proper- lies can be described by the change in the S parameter- The £'-r-(30) and Z. parameters were determined on the basis of molecules in which the increase in charge- transfer character, induced by the solvent polarity, does not involve a change in the geometry of the molecules- For the TNS probe it is suggested that an excited charge-transfer state, with increased planarily between inlyl and naphihyl of the molecule, is formed on in- creasing the solvent polarity. The linearity of the emis- sion maximum of TNS and of the Y parameter of Winstein (r= 0-999S) [16] with the 5 parameter in hydroxyl solvents indicates the necessity of a geometri- cal change in the probe molecule for a correlation with lilt; 5 parameter- In the mathematical treatment of lierbrandsun and Neufeld [II] the dependence on the 5 parameter is interpreted as if the solvent effect were arising exclusively from the energy necessary for cavi- ty formation (or rearrangement)- For dyes and fluo- rescence probes this seems to be ili«? case only in struc- tured solvents- The observed dependence of the emission maxima of ihe aminocoumarins in hydroxyl solvents on the 5 parameter suggests tlie existence of a geometrical re- laxation in the excited state of these molecules. Fur- ther evidence for this suggestion is found in the strong 98 temperature—viscosity dependence. The difference in the dependence of the emission maximum of la and Ib as a function of 5 can be related to the substituents on the nitrogen atom. The two methyl substituents disturb more strongly the solvent cage and the relaxa- tion process in la will be less hindered. The deviation of the emission maximum of la in water can be ex- plained on the basis of SinanoghTs theory [15].Water is the smallest solvent molecule and will adapt its structure most readily around the probe. In dioxane— water mixtures the change in fluorescence maximum in wavenumbers as a function of the E-^ (30) param- eter is analogous to that in a series of solvents- This is due to the change from a non liydroxyl to a hydroxyl (structured) solvent. The point of inflection is situated for la and Ib as well as for TNS at 30 mole percent dioxane- The occurrence of this inflection point is due to the formation of a structured solvent cage consist- ing of water molecules- In r-butanol—water mixtures the change in fluores- cence maximum in la and Ib is analogous to the TNS probe. The change of the fluorescence maximum should be as in the second linear part in a £'-r'(30) ver- sus ?„,„ plot. The occurrence of an inflection point at six mole percent off-butanol is due to a solvent sorting of the solvent mixture. The surrounding of the piobe is different of the constitution of the bulk sol- vent mixture. Addition off-butanol to water enhances the organisation of ihe aqueous phase. The alcohol molecules aggregate and the hydrophobia probe will be surrounded preferably by the alipliatic region of the alcohol molecules [24]. Further increase oftlie t- butanol content destroyed this structure and the change in fluorescence maximum reflects tlie solvent composition- These results indicate that the suggestion by Reeves and by Kosower, concerning solvent influence in fluo- rescence probes sucli as TNS, can be coupled to a more general picture of solvent influence on tlie emissive properties oftlie probe- Acknowledgement The authors are indebted to the Belgian National Science Foundation, the Ministry of Scientific Pro- gramming and the University Research Fund for finan- cial assistance to tlie laboratory- L.C. is indebted to Hie IWONL for a doctoral fellowship. head.ce:title: Influence of solvent properties on fluorescence probes. 7-amino- and 7-n-dimethylamino-4-methylcoumarin

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Chemistry, University of Leuven, B-3030 Heverlee, Belgium

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The shift of the maximum wavenumber of 7-amino- and 7-N-dimethylamino-4-methylcoumarin as a function of solvent properties is investigated and compared to that of other probes. The observed changes are interpreted on the basis of solvent polarity and, specially, of solvent cohesion, unifying previous interpretations by Kosower and Reeves.
